Log In UNDERSTANDING ALTER EGOS WHAT IS AN ALTER EGO? The term "alter ego" comes from Latin, meaning "other self" or "second self. " It represents a distinct identity that coexists alongside a person’s primary self, embodying different characteristics, behaviors, and strengths. ​ More than just a concept, t he alter ego is a powerful mindset strategy that helps individuals unlock their full potential . By creating a separate persona, you can step beyond fears, self-doubt, and limitations—tapping into qualities that may remain dormant in your everyday self. ​ An alter ego serves as a mental tool for transformation, allowing you to shift into a more confident, resilient, or high-performing version of yourself. This practice often involves crafting a detailed persona, visualizing its traits, and even adopting physical cues—like clothing or gestures—that reinforce the identity. Whether drawn from real-life role models or fictional inspirations, an alter ego empowers individuals to break barriers and perform at their best. ORIGINS OF ALTER EGO Personas, pen names, public image, and sub-personalities In the world of psychology, experts like Carl Jung have talked a lot about personas. They see personas as the social masks we wear, the way we present ourselves to others. It's like a way of communicating who we are and how we want to be recognized. People use personas for different reasons - to be more attractive, to make new friends, or to keep their real identities hidden. When it comes to managing their public image, famous people often use personas strategically. It helps them shape their roles and connect their inner selves to the outside world. ​ Authors often use pen names for various purposes. Some do it to stand out more or to create some distance from their other works. You might have heard of Mary Ann Evans, who wrote under the pen name George Eliot, or Amandine Aurore Lucile Dupin, who went by the pseudonym George Sand. ​ Philosophers like Ken Wilber and psychologist John Rowan believe that, on average, we all have around twelve subpersonalities. These subpersonalities represent different parts of our personalities, beliefs, and behaviors. They can have a big influence on how we act and see ourselves in different situations. Take, for instance, the inner critic - it can either be seen as a foe or a friend. The concept of subpersonalities helps us understand the different sides of ourselves and work towards a more balanced and integrated sense of who we are. WHY DO WE NEED ALTER EGOS? We all have a trapped self , a part of us that hesitates to step into the spotlight or fully embrace our true desires. At times, you may find yourself in a self-suppressive mindset, avoiding aspects of who you are and who you aspire to be. This cycle creates a trapped self, where your true potential remains untapped. By becoming clear about your intentions, identifying the benefits you derive from an activity, and determining what you want to achieve in the field of play, you can break free from this self-suppressive cycle and unlock the extraordinary version of yourself—the heroic self that lies within. It's during moments of boredom, anxiety, anger, jealousy, resistance, overwhelm, or fear that we can't simply reason our way out. Our gut instinct tells us to avoid these situations altogether. But what if there was a way to tap into the unconscious power within us, delve into the mysteries of our imagination, and, with practice, change the gut feeling that holds us back? This is where the Alter Ego comes into play. ​ Alter Ego is not just reserved for celebrities, performers, or superheroes.; it is for real people facing real challenges to perform extraordinarily. It allows you to nurture and bring forth the part of yourself that shows up unexpectedly, unveiling hidden strengths and capabilities precisely when you need them the most. It's about harnessing the power of your alter ego and using it to navigate the complexities of life with confidence and resilience. ​ With Alter Ego, you gain a valuable tool to handle adversity with greater resilience. It encourages you to explore your creative side while safeguarding the fragile aspects of yourself. By intentionally crafting and embodying the persona you aspire to be in the field of play, you can unlock a new level of personal growth and triumph over obstacles. ALTER EGO COMMUNITY'S 10 STEPS TO YOUR EXTRAODINARY We combine self-awareness strategies with the science of storytelling, and the fun of community to ensure that your transformational experience is systematic, sustainable, and effortless. 1 Clarify your purpose and set clear intentions for your personal and professional growth. Develop Intent 6 What motivates your heroic self, what name does it go by, and what symbol activates its powers? Craft an Alter Ego 2 Make sense of your evolution; understanding the influences of friends, family, and career choices. Understand your Evolution 7 This transcends mere character crafting-what are the values, daily habits, and behaviours of your alter ego? Build New Habits 3 Forgiveness paves the way to taking control and ownership of your life, necessary for the journey ahead. Embrace Gratitude 8 your training ground to experiment with behaviours, assess, and translate values into tangible actions. Unleash Alter Ego 4 finding our strengths and cultivating unwavering belief in ourselves and our capabilities. Develop Self-Belief 9 We need our North Star – our new productive belief system to help us make choices that align with our evolving self. Build New Belief Systems 5 recognizing what matters most and charting the expansive scope of your growth. Goal-setting & Prioritization 10 ​ Step 10 is about merging your hero self with the every day you. You become the hero or your hero becomes you. Integration & Becoming Programs to your Extraordinary ROLE OF A STRANGERS COMMUNITY IN ALTER EGO Strangers can play a valuable role in supporting you as you explore your alter ego and work on your personal growth. Here are some ways: Safe Space Sometimes, it can be easier to open up to strangers than to people you know well. This is because strangers have no preconceived notions or expectations of you, and you can provide a safe space for you to explore different aspects of your personality and try out your alter ego without fear of rejection. Objective Feedback When you interact with strangers, you can get an objective perspective on your behaviour and the impression you're making with your new behaviours and alter ego. This feedback can be valuable as you refine your alter ego and work on becoming your best self. Provide Inspiration Sometimes, seeing how strangers interact with the world can provide inspiration for your alter ego. You may observe someone who embodies the qualities you want to develop, or who has overcome challenges similar to your own. By watching and learning from strangers, you can gain insights and ideas for how to develop your alter ego and achieve your goals. Act as a Sounding Board Strangers can be great sounding boards as you work through issues related to your alter ego and personal growth. They can listen to your ideas, offer different perspectives, and help you process your thoughts and feelings. This can be particularly helpful when you're facing challenges or feeling stuck in your growth process. Experience Community Our "Becoming by Giving" Philosophy We learn through action, not just theory. Volunteering is the best way to grow—teach in a slum school to build public speaking, help women artisans hone leadership, or work on grassroots campaigns to sharpen problem-solving. Our community provides you with a safe space to try, experiment, and motivate self-action with impact-driven objectives. ​ This is how we unleash our superheroic Alter Ego—after all, who is a superhero but a commoner who shows up in a crisis? ​ Remember, the 8-year-old you is counting on you. Alter Ego, a music focused cocktail lounge, “will offer an energetic vibe and proper, soulful hospitality,” said Ferrell Alvarez, chef, partner and co-owner of Proper House Group. Alter Ego’s Front Lounge – Photo: Gin Design Group Proper House Group is no stranger to strengthening Tampa’s expanding dining scene. From Rooster & the Till, a recent recipient of Michelin’s Bib Gourmand Award to a variety of Sparkman Wharf restaurant concepts, Proper House Group aims to captivate their patrons. “Alter Ego will boast a curated musical experience alongside a monochromatic design that includes intimate seating as well as social spaces,” according to Alvarez. The addition of Alter Ego exemplifies what Water Street Tampa is all about! Awarded the Urban Land Institute’s America Award for Excellence 2023, which shines light on public-private partnerships between developers, local government and community leaders. Chef Alvarez passionately states, “We are committed to thoughtfully offering new and diverse experiences within the district for those who live, work and visit us.” Alter Ego’s Side and Back Lounge – Photo: Gin Design Group Alter Ego is Proper House Group and Alvarez’s fifth endeavor in the neighborhood, showcasing the strong relationship between the community and restauranteur. Other concepts from Proper House Group in the area include Ash, an Italian-inspired restaurant, Gallito Taqueria, Dang Dude, and Lunch Lady at Sparkman Wharf. Once again proving Tampa is on the culinary and hot-spot map, this upcoming concept is sure to find its groove. Executive Director Board Operations | Administration 727-570-5151                                    ext. 22 wren@tbrpc.org Wren G. Krahl serves as the Executive Director for the Tampa Bay Regional Planning Council. Through her duties she works closely with the TBRPC Chair and Council Members in the overall administration of the Council’s mission. As a SHRM certified Professional in Human Resources (PHR) and a HRCI Certified Professional (CP), her other duties include serving as the Human Resources Officer for the organization as well as overseeing Florida State Record Management requirements. She is also responsible for the planning, coordination and implementation of Council related conferences, events and meetings as well as Council publications. Wren has been a resident of the St. Petersburg area for 44 years, is an Honors graduate of Eckerd College in American Studies, and has been with the Council since 1998. Cara Woods Serra AICP, CFM Planning Director/Deputy Executive Director Program Management | Council Subcommittees 727-570-5151                                    ext. 28 cara@tbrpc.org Cara Woods Serra, AICP, CFM serves as the Planning Director/Deputy Executive Director for the Tampa Bay Regional Planning Council. In this role, she oversees the agency’s planning activities and leads initiatives related to disaster preparedness, hazard mitigation, and regional resiliency policy. She has a land use planning background and previously worked on special area plans, long range plans, development review and floodplain management at the local government level. Cara supports the work of hazard mitigation professionals throughout the Tampa Bay region in an effort to facilitate knowledge sharing and regional consistency. Cara has a Bachelor’s degree in Interdisciplinary Social Sciences from the University of South Florida and a Master of City and Regional Planning from the Georgia Institute of Technology. Sarah Vitale AICP Director of Civic Technology Planning | Urban Design | Decision Support Technologies 727-570-5151                                    ext. 27 sarah@tbrpc.org Sarah Vitale, AICP serves as the Director of Civic Technology for the Tampa Bay Regional Planning Council. She specializes in urban design visualization, GIS mapping, and 3D modeling, and provides planning and technical support across the Council’s projects and programs. Sarah holds a Bachelor of Science in Interdisciplinary Social Science and a Master of Science in Planning, both from Florida State University. She is a member of the American Planning Association’s American Institute of Certified Planners and the Congress for the New Urbanism. Maria Robles Manager of Administration/Public Information Board Liaison | Website & Event Management | Graphic Design | Spanish Translations | Public Information State of Florida RMLO | Agency Public Records Custodian 727-570-5151                                    ext. 11 maria@tbrpc.org Maria Robles serves as the Manager of Administration/Public Information and Board Liaison for the Tampa Bay Regional Planning Council. She is trilingual (Spanish, English, and French) and specializes in graphic and website communications. Maria manages the English to Spanish translations for the annual Disaster Planning Guide publication. She also serves as staff for the Courtney Campbell Causeway Scenic Highway. Maria holds a Bachelor of Science degree in Criminology, a minor in French, an Associate of Arts degree in Graphic Design, and a Certificate of International Studies. She graduated from the University of Tampa with Cum Laude Honors distinction. She was born in Mexico City and now lives in Tampa with her beagle Aqua and hedgehog Redgie. Allison supports TBRPC’s planning efforts through spatial analysis, cartography, and data visualization. She has experience with vulnerability assessments, tree canopy analyses, and urban heat studies. Allison holds a Bachelor of Science in Environmental Science, with a concentration in Sustainability, from the University of Tampa and a Master of Science in Environmental Science & Policy, with a Geographic Information Science Graduate Certificate, from the University of South Florida. Amy Bidwell Principal Hazard Mitigation Planner Hazard Mitigation | Vulnerability Assessments 727-570-5151                                    ext. 34 amy@tbrpc.org Amy Bidwell serves as a Principal Hazard Mitigation Planner for the Tampa Bay Regional Planning Council. Her role with the Council involves hazard mitigation planning, vulnerability assessments, and the Regional Local Mitigation Strategy Working Group. She has an emergency management, hazard mitigation planning, and floodplain management background at the local government level leading large planning efforts and projects in Hillsborough and Pasco counties. Notable projects include the most recent Coastal Flood Insurance Rate Map (FIRM) updates, Community Rating System re-verifications, Local Mitigation Strategy Plan development, review and updates, and deployment to Tallahassee during times of disaster to serve as a Disaster Recovery Center Coordinator. A New Jersey native and longtime Florida resident of 41 years, Amy has a Master of Geography degree from the University of South Florida. Meghan Maraia Blancher Coastal Ecologist Resiliency Coalition | Planning Research 727-570-5151                                    ext. 24 meghan@tbrpc.org Meghan Maraia Blancher serves as Coastal Ecologist for the Tampa Bay Regional Planning Council. After graduating from Eckerd College with Bachelor’s degree in Marine Science, she has supported federal and state research in fields including fisheries and water quality. She has since graduated from Virginia Tech with a Masters of Natural Resources and uses her biological experience to assess environmental vulnerability and craft resilience-focused action plans. Meghan is also involved with the Tampa Bay Estuary Program’s Community Advisory Committee and is a member of the American Society of Adaptation Professionals. Charity Franks Hazard Mitigation Planner & LEPC Coordinator Hazard Mitigation | HMEP & LEPC 727-570-5151                                    ext. 10 charity@tbrpc.org Charity Franks serves as a Hazard Mitigation Planner and the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) Coordinator for the Tampa Bay Regional Planning Council. She specializes in disaster preparedness, hazard mitigation planning, and grant writing. She has extensive experience in emergency management, public safety, vulnerability assessments, and hazards analyses. Charity supports the work of emergency management professionals and first responders throughout Florida, facilitating training, regional cooperation, and ensuring regulatory compliance. Charity is a proud alumna of AmeriCorps. She holds a Bachelor of Science Degree in Finance from the University of South Florida. Julie Haskell Administrative Planning Tech Accounting Liaison | Office Management 727-570-5151                                    ext. 16 julie@tbrpc.org Julie serves as the Administrative Planning Tech for the Tampa Bay Regional Planning Council. She supports the Manager of Administration/Public Information and assists in multiple areas such as accounting, office management, and administration. Julie holds a Master’s degree in Business Administration and a Bachelor of Science degree in Technical Management with a focus on Project Management, and is working toward a certificate in Accounting. She graduated from Keller School of Business Management with Magna Cum Laude Honors distinction and from DeVry University with Manga Cum Laude Honors distinction.  She was born and raised in the Metro Detroit area, and now lives in New Port Richey, caring for her 3 cats Ravin, Jewels, and Laya. Mesly Mata Gulf Research Program Fellow Resiliency and Environmental Planning/Research 727-570-5151                                    ext. 12 mesly@tbrpc.org Mesly Mata is a Fellow through the National Academies’ Gulf Research Program , currently partnered with the Tampa Bay Regional Planning Council. She holds a Bachelor of Science in Biology from the University of Oklahoma and a Master of Sustainable Development Practice from the University of Florida. Mesly has contributed to a range of projects that address environmental and social injustices, working with marginalized communities such as low-income immigrant populations in the Oklahoma City metropolitan area and Indigenous groups in the Brazilian Amazon. With an interdisciplinary approach, she is passionate about fostering inclusive spaces where diverse stakeholders can collaborate to develop equitable solutions to the critical social and climate challenges facing the Gulf region. Ashley Mott GISP GIS Manager Geographic Information Systems 727-570-5151                                    ext. 70 ashley@tbrpc.org Ashley Mott, GISP serves as the Geographic Information Systems (GIS) Manager for the Tampa Bay Regional Planning Council. She supports TBRPC’s planning efforts through GIS modeling, spatial analysis, data visualization, and cartography. Ashley earned an extended Bachelor of Science in Land Use, with concentrations in GIS and Meteorology, from the Metropolitan State University of Denver. She also earned a Master of Science in Geographic Information Science from the University of Denver. Ashley is a member of the Geospatial Professional Network and volunteers for its GISCorps program. Alison Prater Disaster Recovery Grants Coordinator Grant Assistance/Economic Development 727-570-5151                                    ext. 13 alison@tbrpc.org Alison Prater serves as a Disaster Recovery Grants Coordinator for the Tampa Bay Regional Planning Council. She holds a Bachelor’s degree in Political Science from Creighton University and is currently pursuing a Master’s degree in Global Development from Harvard Extension School with a concentration in sustainable cities and communities. Alison obtained a certificate in Grant Writing from the Nonprofit Leadership Center and is working towards a Project Management certification. She specializes in climate risk analysis, environmental justice, sustainable community development and socio-ecological systems thinking. Alison is passionate about improving social equity and environmental resilience in the Tampa Bay Region. Alana Todd Principal Environmental Planner Agency on Bay Management | Bay Soundings | Stormwater Management 727-570-5151                                    ext. 40 alana@tbrpc.org Alana Todd serves as the Principal Environmental Planner for the Tampa Bay Regional Planning Council. Alana supports the Council’s work on regional environmental management and resilience-related activities, including the Agency on Bay Management (ABM). She also serves as staff for the TBRPC environmental journal Bay Soundings (now in its 20th Year), the Florida Department of Transportation’s Stormwater Grant Education Funding, and the Stormwater Management Committee. Alana holds a BS in Environmental Science and Policy and BA in Anthropology from the University of South Florida St. Petersburg, as well as a Master of Science in Marine-Estuarine and Environmental Science with a concentration in Environment and Society from the University of Maryland. She represents the Council on various environmental committees and agencies within the six-county region. Courtney Wright LEED GA Senior Sustainability Planner Climate Pollution Reduction Grants | Regional Resiliency Action Plan 727-570-5151                                    ext. 30 courtney@tbrpc.org Courtney Wright, LEED GA serves as a Senior Sustainability Planner for the Tampa Bay Regional Planning Council. She is the Program Manager for the Environmental Protection Agency’s Climate Pollution Reduction Grants (CPRG) Program. Courtney assists in the planning and technical support for the Resiliency Coalition through the Regional Resiliency Action Plan and also supports staff with environmental planning and energy-related initiatives. Courtney holds a Bachelor of Science in Biology from the University of South Florida. She also holds a Master of Arts in Global Sustainability with a concentration in Sustainability Policy, and a graduate certificate in Climate Change and Sustainability from the University of South Florida. She holds a Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design – Green Associate (LEED GA) accreditation and is also a member of U.S. Green Building Council (USGBC) Florida and USGBC Tampa Bay chapter. Learn more or close to accept. × Skip to content Stories Guides Events Shop About Stories Guides Events Shop About Search Search COMMUNITY PARTNER Eat/Drink Alter Ego, a music-focused cocktail lounge, opening in Water Street Tampa October 12, 2023 • By Andrew Harlan Rendering of Alter Ego October 12, 2023 • By Andrew Harlan 940 SHARES Facebook Twitter Time to play the hits. Proper House Group, the team behind the beloved Rooster & The Till, Nebraska Mini Mart, and Dang Dude, will open a new music lounge called Alter Ego in Water Street Tampa. This new hub will be located on the ground floor of Asher (1050 Water St) and is made possible through the collective efforts of the local ownership team comprised of critically acclaimed Chef Ferrell Alvarez, and partners Chon Nguyen and Ty Rodriguez. “Alter Ego will be a music-forward cocktail lounge, offering an energetic vibe and proper, soulful hospitality,” said Ferrell Alverez, chef, partner, and co-owner of Proper House Group. “The space represents a distinct design contrast to our adjacent sibling concept Ash. Boasting a curated musical experience alongside a monochromatic design that includes intimate seating as well as social spaces.” ADVERTISEMENT Rooftop Pool at Asher Alter Ego brings music and craft drinks to Tampa “We are committed to thoughtfully offering new and diverse experiences within the district for those who live, work, and visit us. The Proper House Group shares that vision and the ongoing partnership has been incredible,” said David Bevirt, Executive Vice President of Corporate Leasing & Strategy at Strategic Property Partners, the developers of Water Street Tampa. “We are thrilled to see yet another exciting concept from Ferrell Alverez make their home at Water Street Tampa.” An opening timeline for the lounge is still TBA. We’ll update the story as more details become available. Recently SPP announced that Water Street Tampa, the transformative new lifestyle destination in Downtown Tampa achieved the WELL Community Certification at the Gold level, becoming the first neighborhood in North America to receive the prestigious distinction. Awarded by the International WELL Building Institute, the certification celebrates Water Street Tampa’s successful integration of design and policy decisions that promote health and well-being across all aspects of the neighborhood. Leading to this certification, Water Street Tampa was the first neighborhood in the world to pilot the WELL Community Standard in 2017. News Alter Ego CEO: “What’s the point of even running a VALORANT division now?” by Juandi May 27, 2025 by Juandi May 27, 2025 Alter Ego’s departure leaves only FULL SENSE, Oasis Gaming, and Sharper Esport as the last legacy organizations from Southeast Asia’s earliest VALORANT days still active in the scene. INDONESIA – Alter Ego , one of Indonesia’s largest esports organizations, has officially disbanded its VALORANT division following a disappointing run in VALORANT Challengers SEA Split 2. In a candid livestream earlier this week, Alter Ego CEO and Founder Delwyn Sukamto broke his silence on the decision to pull the plug on the team’s VALORANT division — a title the organization first entered in 2020. A long-standing presence in the local scene, Alter Ego helped shape the early years of Indonesian VALORANT. The organization previously fielded some of the region’s most notable names, including Hagai “ Lmemore ” Tewuh, Rizkie “ BerserX ” Adla Kusuma, David “ xffero ” Monangin, Delbert “ deLb ” Tanoto, and Bryan “ Kushy ” Setiawan. Their early success included a runner-up finish at First Strike Indonesia and several deep runs in pre-franchise APAC events — most notably in the 2021 VALORANT Challengers SEA Stage 3 Playoffs and the 2022 APAC Stage 2 and Last Chance Qualifier. Domestically, Alter Ego remained a top-two contender for years, consistently falling just short of VCT Ascension Pacific qualification — often outshined by their long-time rivals, BOOM Esports. ALSO READ: VALORANT Challengers South Asia Split 2 reaches top three; LAN Finale to take place in Mumbai “Why did our VALORANT division disband? Because our chances to ascend to the franchise league [VCT] are already way too far off, guys,” Alter Ego CEO Delwyn explained in Bahasa Indonesia. “It’s almost impossible for us to make it this year after we didn’t make playoffs in Split 2.” Alter Ego finished fourth in Group A of VALORANT Challengers SEA Split 2, behind Sharper Esport, XGOD, and NAOS Esports — failing to advance to the playoffs. Head coach Nanda “ asteriskk ” Rizana has expressed intent to keep the core trio — Thomas “ Cud ” Alfiantino, Davin “ gotten ,” and Alehandro “ Nakya ” Fabian — together to compete in the Split 3 Relegation/Promotion stage. The 32-year-old CEO also pointed to the broader state of the tier-two ecosystem as another reason for their departure — echoing sentiments previously shared by other org leaders, including those from Disguised and Made in Thailand . “And on top of that, honestly, I think tier-two VALORANT is just in a bad state, guys. Can you believe it’s the tier-two leagues being sold broadcasting rights, not the tier-one franchise league? What the hell, bro? They’re forcing everyone to watch on SOOP. Who even watches on SOOP [ redacted ]? We went from 10,000–20,000 people watching Indonesian VALORANT to just a few hundred. Tell me, what’s the point of even running a VALORANT division now? There’s no publicity [ redacted ]. It’s not even like we’re getting money from SOOP.” (Photo courtesy of VALORANT Esports Indonesia) Despite the exit, Delwyn left the door open for a potential return in the future. “Thank you to everyone who kept supporting us in VALORANT. Maybe it just wasn’t our time yet. We’ve been trying for years… But there’s still a chance we’ll come back and try again next year.” For more insights on the Asian VALORANT scene and upcoming content like this, be sure to like and follow VALO2ASIA on Facebook , Twitter & Instagram .
